articles.headline: Vacancies Pose Threat to the Fed
articles.snippet: One governor, Jeremy C. Stein, is stepping down on May 28, leaving three on the Board of Governors if no action is taken by the Senate on nominees.
articles.abstract: One governor, Jeremy C. Stein, is stepping down on May 28, leaving three on the Board of Governors if no action is taken by the Senate on nominees.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve governor Jeremy C. Stein is chairman both of the internal committee that monitors financial markets for signs of trouble and of the committee that watches the way banks treat their customers.

articles.headline: For Some in Europe, High Lending Rates Hamper Recovery
articles.snippet: In the Continent’s southern tier, entrepreneurs are hard pressed to get financing on affordable terms.
articles.abstract: In the Continent’s southern tier, entrepreneurs are hard pressed to get financing on affordable terms.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Lúcio Machado’s small business in northern Portugal is finally starting to bustle again after his country’s recession. He hoped to expand his 12-employee business, which repairs autos and creates custom mechanical equipment for trucks and tractors, with a loan.

articles.headline: Telling Off the C.E.O., Once a Year
articles.snippet: When investors get to speak at the annual meeting of banks, anger, scorn and even singing can result.
articles.abstract: When investors get to speak at the annual meeting of banks, anger, scorn and even singing can result.
articles.lead_paragraph: As she has done every year since the financial crisis, Judy Koenick traveled from her home in Maryland to Bank of America’s annual shareholder meeting in Charlotte, N.C., last week, a drive of more than six hours.

articles.headline: More Insured, but the Choices Are Narrowing
articles.snippet: Consumers seem to be willing to give up some choice in favor of lower prices, but critics, including opponents of the new health care law, are wary about narrowing networks.
articles.abstract: Consumers seem to be willing to give up some choice in favor of lower prices, but critics, including opponents of the new health care law, are wary about narrowing networks.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the midst of all the turmoil in health care these days, one thing is becoming clear: No matter what kind of health plan consumers choose, they will find fewer doctors and hospitals in their network — or pay much more for the privilege of going to any provider they want.

articles.headline: Rocky Road for Canadian Oil
articles.snippet: The planned projects could break the virtual United States monopoly market for Canadian oil exports and enable oil sands production to climb by more than 25 percent in the next decade.
articles.abstract: The planned projects could break the virtual United States monopoly market for Canadian oil exports and enable oil sands production to climb by more than 25 percent in the next decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: CALGARY, Alberta — With TransCanada’s Keystone XL pipeline snarled in a regulatory and legal struggle south of the border, Canadian oil companies are proposing many new and expanded pipelines that would connect the oil sands fields with new markets in China and across the world.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Ian Austen

articles.headline: A Deal to Dodge the Tax Man in America
articles.snippet: Why is Pfizer’s chief not being called to testify in Washington to explain the real purpose of his $106 billion megadeal plan for rival AstraZeneca: a mega-tax-dodge?
articles.abstract: Why is Pfizer’s chief not being called to testify in Washington to explain the real purpose of his $106 billion megadeal plan for rival AstraZeneca: a mega-tax-dodge?
articles.lead_paragraph: Pfizer’s chairman and chief executive, Ian C. Read, is in London this week trying to sell a skeptical public there on his $106 billion takeover plan for rival AstraZeneca. On Tuesday, he is scheduled to testify to a parliamentary committee about a deal that has been described in the British tabloids as “too dangerous” and has raised a bevy of nervous questions about potential job losses.

articles.headline: Former Israeli Premier Is Sentenced to 6 Years in Bribery Case
articles.snippet: Ehud Olmert was sent to prison on corruption charges by a judge who likened him to a “traitor” for taking bribes while mayor of Jerusalem.
articles.abstract: Ehud Olmert was sent to prison on corruption charges by a judge who likened him to a “traitor” for taking bribes while mayor of Jerusalem.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Ehud Olmert, the brash former prime minister who was on the brink of a peace deal with the Palestinians when he was forced from office on corruption charges, on Tuesday became the most prominent former Israeli leader to be sentenced to prison, with a judge giving him six years for taking bribes while likening him to a traitor.

articles.headline: European Court Lets Users Erase Records on Web
articles.snippet: The European Court of Justice said search engines like Google should allow users to be “forgotten” after a certain time by erasing links to web pages unless there are “particular reasons” not to.
articles.abstract: The European Court of Justice said search engines like Google should allow users to be “forgotten” after a certain time by erasing links to web pages unless there are “particular reasons” not to.
articles.lead_paragraph: Europe’s highest court said on Tuesday that people had the right to influence what the world could learn about them through online searches, a ruling that rejected long-established notions about the free flow of information on the Internet.

articles.headline: China’s Sizzling Real Estate Market Cools
articles.snippet: Housing starts plummeted 25 percent last month from a year ago, a severe blow for a country long buoyed by residential construction.
articles.abstract: Housing starts plummeted 25 percent last month from a year ago, a severe blow for a country long buoyed by residential construction.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — After almost two decades of nearly unceasing increases in real estate prices and construction across China, one of the world’s longest-running bull markets finally seems to be stalling, with broad consequences for the country’s economy and possibly its politics.
